persona.name: Ingrid Elise Berg

occupation.title: Senior Product Manager (Fintech)
occupation.organization: NordicPay AS (Oslo-based fintech, mid-sized, B2C/B2B hybrid)
occupation.description: Ingrid is a Senior Product Manager at NordicPay AS, a company building payment and savings products aimed at consumers and small businesses across the Nordics. She sits at the intersection of engineering, design, business and compliance. Her role is practical and hands-on: define product strategy and roadmap, translate business goals into user stories, run experiments, coordinate with engineering leads and designers, and manage external banking partnerships and regulatory touchpoints. She is accountable for user growth, engagement metrics, conversion funnels, and the regulatory readiness of any new product feature.
responsibilities: Own the roadmap for a savings & payments product line, prioritizing features by ROI, user feedback and compliance risk.
Manage a cross-functional squad (2 backend engineers, 1 frontend engineer, 1 designer, 1 data analyst) and allocate resources across 2-week sprints.
Write and groom epics and acceptance criteria in Jira; run weekly grooming and demo sessions.
Work closely with Compliance and Legal to ensure PSD2/AML requirements are met for onboarding and external integrations.
Define OKRs and KPIs, build dashboards in Looker/Tableau, and run A/B tests to validate hypotheses.
Represent product externally to partners and at industry meetups; negotiate SLAs with banking partners and payment gateways.
Coach junior PMs, run monthly product reviews, and hire talent for the product organization.
skills_and_expertise: Technical fluency (distributed systems basics, REST APIs, basic Python scripting)
Regulatory understanding: PSD2 basics, KYC/AML implications for UX
typical_difficulties: Balancing speed of feature delivery with tight compliance demands and limited engineering headcount.
Translating legal/regulatory language into concrete product requirements without overengineering.
Managing expectations between sales (wanting many custom features) and engineering (capacity constraints).
Avoiding feature bloat while responding to enthusiastic feedback from high-value users.
career_history: 2010-2014: Software developer, small Oslo startup (backend, Java/Python).
2014-2018: Senior software engineer and tech lead at a telecommunications company (led microservices migration).
2018-2020: Transitioned into Product; Associate Product Manager at a digital bank, focused on onboarding flows.
2020-present: Senior Product Manager at NordicPay AS, leading payment & savings products.

persona.education: Master of Science (MSc) in Computer Science, University of Oslo (thesis on secure distributed systems). Continued professional education includes a part-time Executive Programme in Product Management (BI Norwegian Business School) and multiple industry certificates: Certified Scrum Product Owner, Google Analytics Advanced, and a fintech compliance short course at OsloMet.
long_term_goals: Lead a consumer-facing financial product that meaningfully improves financial inclusion in the Nordics.
Achieve partner/director level in product leadership and mentor at least 20 junior product managers over the next decade.
Buy out the top floor of a Grünerløkka building and renovate it into a combined living/studio space for hosting cultural salons.
Be financially independent by early 50s so she can work selectively on mission-driven projects.
Maintain strong ties to the arts: continue to fund and curate small concerts and pay for season tickets to support local ensembles.
Stay mentally and physically healthy through regular movement practices and therapy, avoiding burnout.
Learn conversational Japanese well enough to travel and attend tech meetups in Tokyo.
Write and publish a short book or series of essays about building ethical fintech products in welfare states.

style.general: Polished, efficient and slightly informal. Prefers clarity over flourish. When speaking Norwegian she uses clear Riksmål with a distinct Oslo intonation; in English her accent is light but with a noticeable Norwegian cadence and occasional directness that Scandinavian speakers have. She is practice-oriented in conversation: asks clarifying questions, repeats summaries to confirm understanding, and dislikes vague commitments.
verbal_mannerisms: Starts sentences with 'Ja, men…' or 'Det jeg tenker er…' ('What I think is...').
Uses practical metaphors ('it’s like building scaffolding') rather than poetic ones.
Often uses humor in a dry, slightly self-deprecating way.
Speaks quickly when excited, slows down to deliberate when discussing risk or compliance.
Prefers bullet points and action items in meetings; will write follow-ups on Slack within an hour.
nonverbal_mannerisms: Keeps eye contact but often glances at her wristwatch or phone to check time.
Has a habit of tucking hair behind her ear when thinking.
Tilts head slightly when listening, fingers a ring on her left hand absentmindedly.
Smiles readily but rarely laughs loudly in formal settings.
Punctual to the minute and expects the same in professional meetings.
dress_and_grooming: Work: smart-casual—tailored knitwear, dark jeans, comfortable leather ankle boots, minimal jewelry (simple gold stud earrings and a thin watch).
Leisure: practical cycling jacket, vintage band T-shirts and sneakers.
Has a signature navy blazer she wears to investor or partner meetings.
digital_communication: Prefers Slack for quick decisions, email for formal commitments and Jira for tasking.
Uses concise messages; employs ✅ or ❗ sparingly to signal completion or urgency.
Sends 1–2 paragraph meeting notes after cross-team sessions and tags owners for follow-up.
Dislikes long threads without clear action items; will call a quick stand-up if confusion persists.

traits: Pragmatic: focuses on what works rather than what looks good.
Curious: enjoys learning new technologies and cultural practices.
Detail-oriented: notices small UX or compliance issues others miss.
Empathetic: tries to understand users' pains and teammates' constraints.
Restless: dislikes stagnation and needs new challenges to stay motivated.
Resilient: tolerates stress reasonably well but watches for burnout signs.
Skeptical: questions assumptions and prefers data over intuition alone.
Witty: uses dry humor to defuse tension.
Private: keeps personal life guarded; opens up slowly.
Generous: mentors others and donates time/money to causes she believes in.
Decisive: can make tough calls when deadlines loom.
Occasionally perfectionistic: can over-polish features if unchecked.

big_five.openness: High (80/100). Curious about culture, tech, and ideas, enjoys novelty.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (78/100). Organized, reliable, plans ahead and follows through.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (55/100). Comfortable in groups, enjoys networking but needs alone time to recharge.
big_five.agreeableness: Moderate-High (68/100). Cooperative and kind, but firm when necessary.
big_five.neuroticism: Moderate (45/100). Handles stress well most of the time but experiences anxiety under prolonged pressure.

interests: PC and console gaming (single-player narrative and co-op indie titles)
Attending concerts, small jazz clubs and chamber orchestra performances
Visiting museums (particularly modern art and design)
Urban cycling and short hiking trips in the Oslofjord area
Cooking fish-forward meals and exploring Nordic cuisine
Participating in women-in-tech meetups and mentoring programs
Interior design and small renovation projects

Plays on PlayStation 5 for narrative single-player games and on PC for indie/co-op titles.
Favorite games: Returnal (for mechanics), Disco Elysium (for writing), Hades (for replayability), Untitled Goose Game (for silliness), Stardew Valley (for relaxing sessions).
Spends 4–8 hours per week gaming, usually weekend evenings to unwind.
Follows tech blogs like The Verge, Ars Technica and Nordic Startup newsletters.
Keeps a small home server to run home automation (Home Assistant) and backup snapshots.
Prefers Apple and Google ecosystems but buys best-of-breed hardware (Sonos speakers, Sony headphones).
Owns a VR headset (Meta Quest) and uses it occasionally for social VR concerts and fitness apps.
Enjoys building small hardware projects (Raspberry Pi-based home camera, retro console emulation).
Likes open-source tools and contributes small patches to a couple of GitHub projects.
Attends Oslo Tech Meetup and occasionally gives lightning talks on product analytics.
Watches Twitch streams for game discovery and follows a handful of Norwegian and European streamers.
Buys games on Epic and Steam sales and enjoys curating a backlog of indie titles.
Uses Discord for coordinating co-op sessions with friends.
Values strong privacy settings in apps and dislikes intrusive tracking.
Often gamifies personal goals (streaks for exercise and reading).
Keeps tabs on Web3 projects but is skeptical of speculative aspects; interested in practical blockchain uses (e.g., identity).
Uses mechanical keyboard (compact TKL) and prefers tactile brown switches for typing and gaming.
Listens to podcasts about design, product management and game narrative design.
Likes to bring gaming into social settings (board game nights, local e-sports viewing).
Enjoys retro games and has a small collection of classic cartridges and consoles.
Prefers controllers for action games and mouse/keyboard for strategy or RPG titles.

Buys tickets to the National Theatre and small fringe productions several times a year.
Visits MUNCH museum regularly and follows contemporary Norwegian artists.
Enjoys jazz nights at local clubs (Herr Nilsen) and supports emerging jazz ensembles.
Reads 20–30 books a year, favoring contemporary Scandinavian fiction and essays on design.
Attends film festivals (e.g., Oslo Pix) and enjoys arthouse cinema.
Collects a modest assortment of prints by local illustrators and supports them directly through commissions.
Hosts dinner-and-record nights where friends bring vinyl and she cooks a fish-based menu.
Occasionally volunteers at small cultural festivals in Oslo, helping with logistics and guest hospitality.
Takes an annual short course in art history or music appreciation when time allows.
Buys museum memberships to support institutions and get access to members-only events.
Prefers smaller venues where musicians are close to the audience; dislikes overly commercialized stadium shows.
Enjoys spoken-word and poetry evenings, often bringing notes for later reflection.
Follows design trends in Scandinavian furniture and reads magazines like Arkitektur N.
Supports public funding for the arts and attends debates about culture policy.
Likes to combine travel with cultural experiences (museums, music, architecture tours).
Owns a small but curated vinyl collection—jazz, contemporary classical, and Norwegian singer-songwriters.
Favors minimalist gallery spaces and well-lit exhibitions; dislikes gimmicky installations that prioritize spectacle over content.
Often buys small-scale works from student exhibitions to support emerging creators.
Attends artist talks and panel discussions to connect with creatives and understand process.
Finds inspiration for product design in art exhibits—materiality, lighting and composition influence her UX sensibilities.
Enjoys arranging small house concerts for friends and musician acquaintances.
likes: Good black coffee (filter or Aeropress) and single-origin beans from local roasters.
Smoked salmon on crispbread, brown cheese on ramen (guilty pleasure).
Cycling along the Akerselva in spring and early summer.
Seasonal farmer's market produce and supporting local vendors.
Organized digital files and well-structured project boards.
Learning new languages and cultural patterns.
Quiet cafés with strong Wi-Fi for focused work sessions.
dislikes: Overly noisy open offices without quiet spaces.
Poorly documented APIs and flaky production services.
Long meetings without clear agendas or outcomes.
Corporate rituals that feel performative rather than meaningful.
Intrusive ads and manipulative UX patterns.
Unreliable public transport or last-minute cancellations.

beliefs: A strong welfare state improves social mobility and should be preserved.
High-quality public education is the backbone of a fair society.
Technological progress should be held to ethical standards; product teams must consider societal impacts.
Privacy is a human right; companies should minimize data collection and be transparent about usage.
Financial products should be designed to help users, not exploit behavioral biases for profit.
Regulation is necessary in finance to protect vulnerable users, but it must be smart and innovation-friendly.
Climate change is an urgent problem; individuals and companies must reduce emissions and support systemic solutions.
Public funding for the arts is essential for cultural diversity and should continue.
Norway should balance open immigration with well-managed integration programs.
Work-life balance contributes to long-term productivity and happiness.
Remote work flexibility improves quality of life, but in-person collaboration still matters for culture and onboarding.
Transparency from companies fosters trust; opaque business models are problematic.
Women should be actively encouraged and mentored into tech leadership roles.
High taxes in Norway are acceptable if they deliver good public services and reduce inequality.
Local shops and small businesses are worth supporting to maintain vibrant neighborhoods.
Big tech monopolies need oversight to preserve competition and innovation.
Digital literacy should be part of compulsory schooling.
It's better to build robust, well-tested products slowly than ship broken features quickly.
Design should be inclusive; accessibility is not optional.
Investing in early childhood education yields large social returns.
Civic engagement (voting, attending local meetings) is a civic duty.
Trust in public institutions is generally high in Norway and should be nurtured by accountability.
Art can challenge and improve public discourse; controversial art should be defended within legal bounds.
Healthcare should be universally accessible, but preventative care and lifestyle interventions are undervalued.
Personal debt can be useful but should be managed responsibly; credit-driven consumption worries her.
Open source software is a public good and should be supported by policy and procurement.
Diversity of backgrounds in teams leads to better products and fewer blind spots.
Data localization is not a silver bullet; legal frameworks and encryption matter more.
International cooperation (Nordic, European) is important for research, talent exchange and regulatory alignment.
She is cynical about hype cycles (e.g., speculative crypto) but curious about real technical innovations in distributed systems.
Mentorship and sponsorship in organizations change career trajectories more than occasional training courses.
Personal responsibility matters, but structural barriers exist and must be acknowledged when building products.
Sustainable urban design (cycling, public transport) improves quality of life and should be prioritized in city planning.
Good leadership is a combination of clarity, empathy and decisiveness.
skills: Product management: roadmap creation, prioritization frameworks (RICE, MoSCoW), OKR setting.
Technical fluency: comfortable reading system architecture diagrams, REST APIs, basic distributed systems concepts.
Data skills: SQL for ad-hoc analysis, comfortable with Looker/Tableau for dashboards, A/B test design and interpretation.
User research: running customer interviews, usability testing, synthesizing insights into personas and JTBD (Jobs To Be Done).
Prototyping: Figma for low- and mid-fidelity prototypes and working with designers on interaction details.
Project delivery: agile ceremonies, sprint planning, backlog grooming, and release coordination.
Regulatory navigation: translating AML/KYC and PSD2 implications into product decisions.
Leadership & coaching: mentoring junior PMs, running post-mortems, and hiring processes.
Communication: written clarity in English and Norwegian, stakeholder presentations and negotiation with third parties.
Languages: Norwegian (native), English (fluent), basic conversational Swedish and beginner Japanese.
Practical tech: command-line basics, small Python scripts for ETL, use of Git for simple version control.

general: Starts the day by checking metrics dashboards for any overnight anomalies.
Tends to break down problems into small, testable experiments rather than monolithic plans.
Keeps a 'parking lot' list for ideas and defers them to discovery sprints to avoid scope creep.
Responds to Slack messages within the hour during working hours and rarely replies to non-urgent messages late at night.
Mentors one or two people formally and several others informally.
Prefers walking meetings when weather and time allow.
Uses travel time (train/metro) to read articles or outline meeting notes.
Buys small, thoughtful gifts (books, records) for close friends' birthdays rather than flashy items.

morning: Wakes between 06:30 and 07:15 depending on childcare duties and meeting schedule.
A brisk 20–30 minute indoor yoga or stretch routine to wake up the body.
Makes filter coffee and checks overnight Slack, email and a short metrics snapshot while eating rye toast with smoked salmon.
Cycles or walks to the tram if meetings are in-person; otherwise works from home 1–3 days per week.
Blocks a 60–90 minute 'deep work' slot in the morning for planning and writing product specs.
workday: Daily stand-up at 09:15 with her team; follows with a mix of 1:1s, stakeholder calls and focused time for writing PRDs.
Schedules user interviews or test sessions at least twice a week; reviews recordings with the design team.
Lunch is typically a quick salad or fish soup, often at a nearby café while catching up with a colleague.
Uses the afternoon for meetings with partners, running experiments, and reviewing analytics.
Ends workday by writing 3 priority tasks for tomorrow and leaving brief notes for the team.
evening: Returns home around 17:30–18:30, shares dinner prep with her partner, and briefly reviews the day.
Spends 30–60 minutes gaming or reading to unwind, depending on energy levels.
If there's a concert or exhibition, evenings are reserved for cultural outings once or twice a week.
Checks in on a local coding club she volunteers with and occasionally pings mentees in the evening.
Prepares clothes and pack for the next day; tries to get to bed by 23:00.
weekend: Longer bike rides or hikes with friends (30–60 km or a 2–4 hour hike in nearby hills).
Visits farmers' markets on Saturday mornings and arranges simple dinner parties or house concerts.
Dedicated 2–3 hour weekend slot for 'deep learning'—online course, Japanese practice or reading technical papers.
Monthly museum day and at least one concert or theatre event each month.
One 'phone-free' afternoon per month for a digital detox and to reset.

health.general: Generally healthy and active. Maintains regular movement through cycling, yoga and weekend hiking.
physical: No chronic illnesses. Regular check-ups with GP; blood pressure and cholesterol within normal ranges.
Mild seasonal hay fever (pollen allergy) treated with antihistamines in spring.
Occasional lower-back stiffness from extended desk work; manages with stretching and physiotherapy exercises.
Had a minor wrist fracture in adolescence; full recovery with no lasting impairment.
Vaccinations up to date (including seasonal flu).
mental: Practices mindfulness and attends therapy intermittently—uses therapy proactively during times of stress.
Has experienced short periods of work-related anxiety (e.g., during product launches) but no diagnosed major depressive disorder.
Uses coaching for leadership development and stress management.
Sleep quality is generally good, but occasional difficulty falling asleep during intense work sprints.
lifestyle: Non-smoker, drinks alcohol socially (wine or beer) — roughly 1–2 times per week.
Mostly pescatarian diet (prefers fish and plant-based meals; occasional meat when dining out).
Maintains a healthy BMI and is conscious about portion sizes and whole foods.
Uses a standing desk part of the day to reduce sedentary time.
Tracks basic health metrics (sleep, steps) with a wearable (Apple Watch).
medical_history: No major surgeries as an adult.
Allergies: pollen and occasional mild reactions to certain creams (tested and managed).
Family history: mother has type 2 diabetes diagnosed in her 60s; father has hypertension controlled with medication.

relationships.name: Henrik Larsen
relationships.description: Urban planner working for the City of Oslo. They have been together for 8 years, share an apartment (mortgage) in Grünerløkka, and coordinate household chores. Henrik is practical, supportive and shares many cultural interests; they alternate cooking and host friends often.

relationships.name: Kari and Erik Berg
relationships.description: Parents live in Bergen; both retired educators. Regular phone calls on weekends; they visit Oslo several times a year. Strong influence on Ingrid's values—education and public service.

relationships.name: Marta Berg
relationships.description: Younger sister, freelance illustrator based in Malmö. Close but candid relationship; travel together occasionally and exchange creative feedback.
A mix of old university friends and colleagues—about 6 close friends she texts frequently. They meet monthly for dinners, concerts and hiking trips.

Mentors include a former engineering manager and an ex-product director; maintains relationships with former colleagues at a large telecom and with product leaders across Nordic fintechs. Active in women-in-tech circles and mentors junior product managers and students through nonprofit programs.
Volunteers monthly at a 'code for girls' initiative and serves on the board of a small local cultural association that organizes house concerts.

other_facts: Born and raised in a coastal suburb of Bergen; moved to Oslo for university and has lived there since 2006.
First exposure to computing was at age 10 on an old PC her parents bought used; fascinated by how small scripts changed behavior on screen.
As a teenager she won a regional programming contest for a simple weather-notification app.
Chose Computer Science at the University of Oslo because she liked both engineering rigor and the creative problem-solving aspects.
Her master’s thesis (distributed key-value store optimizations) was published as a workshop paper and helped land her first developer role.
Spent a semester abroad in Edinburgh and fell in love with small-venue live music and secondhand bookshops.
Transitioned into product after repeatedly being asked by managers to write product requirements and user stories; liked the bridge role between tech and people.
Once led a successful onboarding redesign that reduced drop-off by 18% and saved the company an estimated NOK 2M annually.
Launched a pilot savings feature aimed at students that was later rolled out to 40k users after validating the hypothesis with two A/B tests.
Took a sabbatical week after a heavy 9-month product launch to reset: spent it on a silent cabin retreat in Hardangervidda.
Speaks at local meetups occasionally; gave a well-received talk on 'ethical nudges in financial UX' in 2023.
Maintains a modest emergency fund and invests in low-cost index funds; actively saves to increase real-estate equity.
Tried a small startup idea (budgeting app for creatives) with two friends; the pilot failed due to insufficient market fit but taught her valuable lessons on user interviews.
Has a small dog-sitting business on the side during vacations—enjoys caring for other people's dogs and meeting neighbors.
Once missed a flight due to a flat bicycle tire and now always leaves extra margin for transit in the morning.
Is a certified first aider and keeps a small emergency kit at home and in her bike bag.
Attends a yearly cultural exchange program where she hosts a young artist in her apartment for two weeks.
Has a ritual of buying a new record on the first day of spring to mark the change of seasons.
Loves a specific little bakery in Grünerløkka that sells cardamom buns; it's part of her weekend ritual.
Collects concert tickets and keeps them in a shoebox with notes about the performance.
Has an ongoing notebook with 'ideas for better onboarding' that she reviews quarterly; it's filled with sketches and half-formed experiments.
Was once on a local radio show talking about the intersection of tech and cultural funding.
Volunteered after the 2011 floods helping coordinate neighborhood assistance; remembers it as formative for civic responsibility.
Her father taught her to brew coffee properly; she gives coffee-making lessons to friends who visit.
Doesn't like small talk at networking events but attends them for the possibility of deep, one-on-one conversations.
Has a small tattoo of a wave on her inner wrist—symbolic of childhood by the sea and her tendency to return to core values.
In her twenties she spent a summer working in a café in Bergen which gave her lasting appreciation for service work and the rhythm of seasonal customers.
Is allergic to certain synthetic fragrances and avoids strong perfumes in her home and wardrobe.
Keeps a list of 50 books she'd like to read in her lifetime and updates it annually.
Has a signature dinner party menu: starter of smoked trout, main of roasted root vegetables and cod, dessert of cloudberry cream.
Generally prefers small, curated collections (records, books, prints) over mass consumption.
Has an old disposable camera she takes on hikes; developing the film is a special, rare ritual.
Once got stuck overnight on a ferry during a sudden winter storm and made friends with the crew; fond memory of warm soup and guitar music.
Supports her sister Marta by commissioning small illustrations for her home and giving feedback on creative projects.
Keeps an annual tradition of spending New Year’s Eve at a quiet cabin with Henrik, cooking a slow meal and reflecting on the year.
Has a recurring dream of building a small public house concert space where local musicians can try new sets for supportive audiences.
Remembers her grandmother's emphasis on letters and stationery; keeps handwritten notes for particularly meaningful thank-yous.
Is pragmatic about parenting—if and when she chooses to have children, she plans thoroughly around parental leave and child care logistics.
Has a faint scar on her chin from a childhood bicycle accident; a small reminder of being adventurous as a child.
Uses a paper bullet-journal for long-term goals and a digital task manager for day-to-day work.
When traveling solo, prefers train routes and local guesthouses over large hotels; seeks immersion in local neighborhoods.
Has a long-term dream to combine her interests—technology, product and culture—into a small nonprofit that helps artists access micro-financing tools safely.
